sub_topic: Calculation of thermodynamic properties of molecules and reactions.
message_1:
Calculate the standard molar entropy change for the reaction: 
2 SO2(g) + O2(g) → 2 SO3(g) at 298 K, given the following standard molar entropies: 
ΔS°(SO2(g)) = 248.2 J K^-1 mol^-1 
ΔS°(O2(g)) = 205.0 J K^-1 mol^-1 
ΔS°(SO3(g)) = 256.2 J K^-1 mol^-1
message_2:
To calculate the standard molar entropy change (ΔS°) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔS°(reaction) = Σ ΔS°(products) - Σ ΔS°(reactants)

For this reaction, we have:

ΔS°(reaction) = [2 × ΔS°(SO3(g))] - [2 × ΔS°(SO2(g)) + ΔS°(O2(g))]

Now, we can plug in the given standard molar entropies:

ΔS°(reaction) = [2 × 256.2 J K^-1 mol^-1] - [2 × 248.2 J K^-1 mol^-1 + 205.0 J K^-1 mol^-1]

ΔS°(reaction) = [512.4 J K^-1 mol^-1] - [496.4 J K^-1 mol^-1 + 205.0 J K^-1 mol^-1]

ΔS°(reaction) = 512.4 J K^-1 mol^-1 - 701.4 J K^-1 mol^-1

ΔS°(reaction) = -189.0 J K^-1 mol^-1

The standard molar entropy change for the reaction is -189.0 J K^-1 mol^-1.
